Replies.Reply: You kill your film several times, mostly by talking about it. A film is a dream. You kill it writing it down, you kill it with a camera; the film might come to life for a moment or two when your actors breathe life back into it - but then it dies again, buried in film cans. Mysteriously, sometimes, in the editing room, a miracle happens when you place one image next to another so that when, finally, an audience sits in the dark, if you're lucky -- very lucky - and sometimes I've been lucky - the dream flickers back to life again. That's why I'm secretive.
Finally, a serious question.
Maestro, Maestro, Maestro Contini...
Buongiorno, Dante.
Bene, grazie, bene.
We all have questions for Signor Contini.
Is he going to follow us?
On my desk.
Under my desk. In the trash. Non lo so.
Get me a cigarette.
Jaconelli -
Ascolta me.
Careful what you say. He's a spy from the bank.
I need a cigarette.
I need a coffee and a cigarette.
Actually and an aspirin.
That's right: that's directing. And it doesn't seem to make a blind bit of difference, finally, what the answer is...
Yes.
Yes, yes.
Soon.
No.
Yes.
No. Nobody. Dante.    And his spy.
Why is there no fire escape in here?

What the hell's wrong with me? I can't sleep. I can't think. I can't write. I can't breathe. My heart is racing. Am I dying, Mamma? I owe you flowers, I know. I'll come to the cemetery at the weekend. You should have let me bury you in Roma, Mamma, I could visit you every week. Don't look at me like that.
I miss you.
Thanks for coming, everybody.
Yes.
Actually, it's my shortest title yet.
Films are not modest. They cost too much, they take too long, and they involve too many people. So they should have grand titles.
Why? I still don't know what my last film was about.
Of course I can tell you what my film is about...I can tell you the story, I can tell you who I am going to cast, the music I want to use, I can tell you everything... but... I... won't.
It sounds fantastic.    I can't wait to see it.
Stephanie.
I'm less interested in the wrapping than what might be inside it.
For good?
I told Luisa that when we got married I would never again make love to my leading lady.
I WOULD LIKE TO BE HERE.
You want me to be serious? In a Press Conference?
I thought I was the clown in this circus.
Flops.
AND IT'S A PROBLEM, ESPECIALLY WHEN MY BODY'S NEARING FIFTY AS MY MIND IS NEARING TEN.
Excuse me?
What would you like to see that I haven't already shown you?
I AM LUSTING FOR MORE, SHOULD I SETTLE FOR LESS?
I WANT TO BE PROUST...
...OR THE MARQUIS DE SADE.
...I WANT TO BE YOUNG, BUT I HAVE TO BE OLD.
SO ARRANGE IT!
THAT'S ALL THAT I WANT!
I need a room.
A suite.
With a view of the sea. A balcony.
I've come from Milano.
On business.    I'm a businessman. Busy busy busy.
Please.
Why not.
Not the flops.
I need to see a doctor. Do you know one who's discreet...? I'd like to see him today, in my room, now, if possible.
And I need to place a call.   To my wife.
Luisa, tesoro...
Is everybody mad at me?
I had to escape from the Press Conference.
Don't tease me. I'm sick, Luisa.
No, but this time I'm really sick.      I can't breathe.
Yes, of course I'm by myself.
Yes, please come, that's why I'm calling, please come straight away.
Great. Marvellous.
I don't know, some spa.   Horrible.   I just kept driving.
And, actually, it's hardly worth it.
But I do wish you were here.
I love you.
This number - if a woman answers you put it through to my room, otherwise...
What?
What is she whispering? Is it my blood pressure? Is it serious? Am I dying?
Pronto.
It's a very an important call, Doctor.
What? Yes, yes. It's about my film.
Carla.
Replies.Didascalie: (to himself, remembering how much work she is)

Replies.Reply: Carla!
Replies.Didascalie: (and now to her, covering his ambivalence)

Replies.Reply: Carlissima.
Of course.
Very happy.
Carla, all those bags for the weekend?
Carla... I have to tell you... they found out who I am at the hotel--
... yes, horrible, but obviously we don't want to be followed by the press, so I found the most charming pensione for you, and it's right here.
Close the curtains, it's too light in here.
Perfect.   Now, go into the corridor---
Shhh! Yes, count to ten and come back in, and pretend you're in the wrong room, and I'm a complete stranger--
I'm here on business.
Go, go.   Wait. Your face.
Get your makeup.
Don't move, Carla.
Uh-huh.
Good for him.
Why not?
Beautiful. When you come in I want you to be my little savage.
Go, go.
Hurry, please, Carla.
I'll pretend to be asleep.
Could you do such a thing?
What happened?
Come here.
What?
Carla, just come here.
Be savage. Show me.
Yes, you have. And I don't have the faintest idea who you are.
Page one, page one, page one...
She takes the man's face and kisses him...
Mother of God, give me a sign.
Excuse me, father...
Buongiorno.
His Excellency, the Cardinal, is he -?
Signor Contini!
I am a big fan.
I would very much like to speak to the Cardinal. Do you think he might grant me -
No.
I'm in need of some guidance, some pointers...
For His Excellency?
I'm sure that would be possible...
I'm not going to ask how you found me.
Oh God.
Really?    You understand?
You're not going to drag me back?
Thank you, my old friend.
Where are we going?
Ciao.
No, I remember you. You were, we all enjoyed you, so to speak.
Did she like the script?
No no no no - impossibile - are you telling me she didn't get the script?
Replies.Didascalie: (gestures for Pierpaolo to light him a cigarette)

Replies.Reply: Pierpaolo!
Claudia didn't get the script! Send her another one. For Chrissake. Send her two!
Cretino!
Yes, yes, that's what I say, people just don't realise - she's an actress as well as a star - I know Dante's dying to talk to you. A dolpo. Ciao.
Yap, yap, yap, yap, yap, yap, yap!
What are we doing here?
What? No. Oh please God. No. I spoke with her yesterday. She didn't even mention it. Give me a cigarette.
What's that?
For which scene?
Looks like the Folies Bergere. It's wrong. Italian women don't wear those things.
Why did people love that film?
I'm trying to find it.
Ashtray.
Thanks. You were saying - my head is jammed up my ass.
Me too.
Do you believe in God?
So do I.
Oh yes, very much so. Not as much as I would like to be, not as much as you would like me to be, I'm sure, but certainly yes, I'm trying.
Yes, yes. I will, I will. Your Eminence, I am not happy. I'm searching for something. I feel a sense of misery, of despair and --
Excuse me - my films are what I imagine.
How do you train the imagination?
I can't breathe, I can't breathe.
If I die it would kill your husband?
I have to go to work. Carla, I can't breathe.
It's impossible.
Because it's impossible. Please.
For the very same reason you don't want me to die on top of you. It's not fair to your husband. It's not fair to my wife.
No.
Let's say there were ten sequences, each one set in a different period, but played by the same cast, a man and a woman, a woman and a man...
Something light and hectic - like Mozart would do it, like Figaro.
Like the circus...
Let's try to dig for something else.
Luisa!
I can't believe you came.
The jungle drums exaggerated just a tiny bit.
I was dying, until just now.    Come.
And don't think I forgot your birthday. When you get home, the house will be full of flowers...
I hope not. Happy Birthday, my darling.
Let's drink a toast to Luisa's birthday.
Happy Birthday.
Ah, Don Mario. Excuse me, darling, this is Don Mario. This is my wife, Luisa.
Replies.Didascalie: (standing up to greet him, then turning to Luisa)

Replies.Reply: Luisa was in that film.
It's true.   It was your first part.
Your name, it's Italian.
What have you done before?
Waited? For this?
Thank you.
Thank you. For what I'm looking at.
Keep running.
Luisa!
Luisa - will you please just tell me what happened?
What lie?
There are plenty of restaurants.
Well you certainly managed to.
I didn't know she was here.   She just turned up.
The only privilege my wife has these days is not having to warn me.
Carla, you have to wait outside.
I'm in the middle of a working dinner with my colleagues.
I'll find someone to escort you home.
Apparently she's staying in some grotesque pensione next to the station.
Luisa, if I'd invited her here, she would be staying in the hotel, wouldn't she? Think about it. I didn't even know you were coming.
Because it's true.
It is. Look, she was worried about me, she came to see if I was all right - which yes, is stupid but not, as far as I know, a crime, and hardly a mortal sin.
What? What are you laughing about?
It's finished. It's finished.
If it wasn't before, it is now.
Vodka.
Yes, I remember very well, Stephanina from Vogue.
Amazing. May I take a cigarette?
Please.
Prego.
Really?
And what truth is that?
I don't think religion is dead. And what exactly is the sexual revolution?
Style.
Okay.
I hate that man.
No.
I love you Luisa.
Can we please try to be close again.
Pronto...
Is the doctor still with her?
I'm here.
Thank you.    I'm going to stay with her now.
Grazie.
Carla, I should call your husband.
What have you done to yourself?    I'm not worth dying for, Carla.
Ssshh. You should rest. We'll talk about everything in the morning...
Rest, rest.   Cara mia...
Hold on to me, Mamma.   Don't let me wake from this.
Yes.
Of course. I'm sorry.
She loves you, you know that, don't you.
Darling?
Where's Luisa?
I can't.
I need help.
I'm not cured.
I need more time.
Okay.
Luisa, it's me. Please don't hang up.
I want you to be with me in the screening room tonight. I want to talk to you about the casting, about the script. Everything...
Otherwise I won't be able to start, I won't know what I'm thinking...
Are you there? Luisa?
I'm not asking you to let me come home, I just want you to come to the screen test tonight. Not for me, but for the movie. You always have, you always do.
Could you turn to the right please, Claudia.
And can you turn to the left.
Now just one slow turn for us.
Bellissima.   Brava.   Cut.
That's fair.
That's fair.
I'll be back.
I'll be right back.
You look ravishing.
It's good to see you.
Why is everybody so suddenly obsessed with the script?

Talk to the people who love you in our films, they're not interested in my script! They're interested in the way you turn your head, the way the camera looks past you to the moon... the way you smile a little as you cry, the way you really do blush for the camera -
Not a million - you're the muses, the incredible women who made Italy what it is today, a country run by men -
The great women...

In a way - yes - you have this man in the story and he's, he wants to take hold of everything, to devour everything, he can't let anything go, or, he doesn't want to, and he changes direction every day, because he's lost, he's dying, he's bleeding to death...
Exactly!   They fall in love with him.
What?
No, you misunderstand...
She's his inspiration.
I fall in love with you every time.
No.
There was a time once, we were on location, some terrible hotel - and you were in the room directly above me and I could hear you walking about...
...and, all through the night, I wanted to rush up the stairs and hammer on your door until you opened.
I don't know. I don't know.
Sure.
It meant so much to us all.    That you came.
What did you think? Did you like anybody or -?
Luisa?
What for?
What are you talking about?
The screen test? You have to understand, it's nothing, this is what I do, I direct. That's my job.
What have I done? What have I done, Luisa?
I CAN'T   MAKE THIS MOVIE, THERE'S   NO WAY THAT I'LL BEGIN IT.
THE PROBLEM IS THE AUTHOR'S LOST CONTROL.
FIND ANOTHER GENIUS, I CAN'T BE ONE OR BECOME ONE.
I destroyed everything, Mamma...
...I destroyed everything, I just...
Old friends, I have to come clean with you.
There is no movie. I can't pretend anymore. We have to stop.
I'm sorry.
She seemed so happy. I didn't want to interfere... Is she with anybody?
I like to get about without everybody pointing at me.
Nowhere. Here. I walk. Just to be able to walk.
No, no. Nobody.
Don't tease me, Lilli.    My heart is -
I just miss her. I should have IDIOT tattooed on my forehead.
Does she? Did she really say that?
No. Never. I've spent this time trying to learn something, Lilli, to not be the person who forgets about everybody else, the person who never grew up.
The only movie I could make now would be... I don't know... would be about a man trying to win back his wife.
I can't remember how you do this.

I don't want to say too much. The first way that we kill our film is by talking about it. But this scene is about reconciliation. And within the scene I would like you to try and find your way to begin that journey back towards each other.
Maybe it's the most important building block that we have to begin again...
Yes.
ACTION.
So what's your favorite pasta?
Good luck, Maestro.
Guido! You're here.
I've been looking for you all over the place. The set's coming along. How are you?
Bene. My God, you look terrible, better go to makeup, forget you've got a press conference?
Yes, makeup and wardrobe.
He's counting costs, you know. The Bank wants him here.
Don't speak to him, I speak to him.
He's not exactly from the bank, Guido.
Not now. He's got the Press Conference.
He needs a shirt and tie, Lilli.
We're running late...
Alright. Two minutes Guido.
Silenzio, per favore...Thank you, thank you...

I want to say a few words from my heart. I am humbled and thrilled to be able to announce that I am producing Guido Contini's next film, Italia, which will star once again Contini's longtime inspiration, the international film star, Claudia Jenssen...
...we start shooting in ten days time in Cinecitta. That makes it one week from Monday.
Thank you, Maestro, thank you very much. This is our ninth film together. Guido Contini.
Our next film will be exactly as it sounds. Italia. It's the very spirit of Italy - Italy as myth, Italy as a woman, Italy as a dream.
Guidino!
Please - it's my job. A producer needs to know where his director is at all times...even to know the pensione where his mistress is staying...
I understand, Guido. Rome is absolutely unbearable. The pressure.
Of course I understand.      Absolutely.
No. You're a genius and genius must be served.
You can't be in Rome. Okay.
Rome will come to you!
It's a fantastic place for you to focus. Everyone is here to help the movie. Everyone is here because they love you, Guido.
Guido...you remember Donatella.
Donatella, you tested her.
Lombardo...
Claudia is going to be amazing.
The screenplay is first of all a map.
Here she is. At last.   Magnificent.
Happy Birthday!
We're going back to Rome.
Luisa? She's gone. She's had it with you.
And quite frankly, so have I. You drag a whole crew up here and then you just disappear.
I can't protect you anymore. And Claudia is in Rome. Makeup tests start today. Remember?
You can't. You must. Don't sit down.
You've had help. You've seen the doctors, you've seen the priests, you've taken the cure.
That's enough! The movie calls, your star has landed. Fausto - take his things please.
Guido! Andiamo!
Forget the script. Claudia's here now.
Tonight.   We'll watch everything tonight and make some decisions.
Tonight.
Claudia!
Fair?
You've got dailies, Guido.
You've got meetings.
Great work, Lilli... Wonderful costume...
...and the hair, makeup, fantastic.
Two great profiles.
And the back isn't too bad.
Fantastic. Guido?     Really nice.
Okay.   Let's see the actresses.
Well they can keep her.
She's peculiar. You don't like her Guido?
She's nice.
Even better. She's a bit nervous here. What do you say, Guido?
Who's this? I thought we were looking for a blonde.
Very tall.
It's not the point.     Guido wants the blonde.
Shh.
She's too beautiful.      For my tastes.
I don't know what Guido thinks. I think we are happy with Donatella.
Great. Anyway, fantastic day, but we have to go home. We have a very, very busy day tomorrow. Thank you very much everybody. Thank you. Okay, well done.
He has no tie.
Signor Contini, I'm Fausto.     Good morning, Signor Contini.
Okay, I have some questions for Signor Contini.
Yes, but please, please, I think it's customary for there to be an approved script and budget before filming commences...
It's not my intention to be difficult.
Not ready?!
Dante, you see, he hasn't written a word...
She's a goddess.
She came directly from Venus.
She's very natural.
She's too tall.
She's not bad, but -
She's beautiful.
Where do you want your messages?
There's no room on your desk.
Some of these are urgent!
Maestro...
Claudia's agent...
Yes, I'm sorry. Right now.
Maestro, the screen tests are back from the lab. Will you watch them now?
Design meeting? Production meeting?
Tonight.
Maestro.
Silence please. Se gira. And we are rolling.
We've got it. Next costume please.
But please, just a couple more costumes, Claudia.
You'll remember.
Maestro, should I call final checks?
Makeup, please! Final checks!
Alora. Silencio per favore. Silence please.
Gyriamo. E alora motore!
We will never be ready to shoot in ten days.
Yes, with the flower and the glass and the arches of the Roman Empire...
Dottore, Dottore. You have actors waiting for you in your office.
Dottore, this way...
Maestro!
It sounds like a masterpiece.
She has a beautiful profile.
Actresses.
If we like her, we have to call her agent right away. Everybody wants her right now.
She's a very funny actress.
She's very beautiful.
Answer a question, I'll give you a coffee. Answer another question, I'll give you a cigarette. And so on.

Calm down. Directing a movie is a very overrated job, we all know it. You just have to say yes or no. What else do you do? Nothing. Maestro - Should this be Red? Yes. Green? No. More extras? Yes. More lipstick? No. Yes, no, yes, no, yes, no - that's directing.
Replies.Didascalie: (turns to Guido and lights a cigarette)

Replies.Reply: So please, Guido, yes or no, do you want any costumes in this film?
You see - simple!
Might I know what period the movie's in?
Replies.Didascalie: (handing him an espresso fetched by her assistant, ROBERTA)

Replies.Reply: You know I don't allow producers in here.
He's gone. Have you written a word of the script?
Are you in a panic?
Is Luisa going with you to the Press Conference?
You need to shave.    You look terrible.
You'll be fine. You're a world class liar, darling, go out there and lie for Italy, lie for Italia.
I'm happy. I brought my swimsuit.
It was Luisa's birthday yesterday.
What's that?
It's for Claudia.
likes something like this, or you do.
Don't knock the Folies Bergere...
...it brings back happy memories.
Oh Guido, don't. That's death.     Every time we have to start again.
You won't find it with your head jammed halfway up your ass.
Halfway. I don't know. Why not dream up something entertaining, Guido?
Ah, Bon soir, bon soir, bon soir. Je suis la vedette des Folies Bergere.
Let me tell you. Last night I looked down at this table in the chairs you are sitting in now, and what did I see? A priest! And next to him?
Ahh, mon Dieu! Guido? Guido Contini?
Feeling better? There's no room for hopelessness in here, is there, Guido?
We must explain something to our young Guido. What do we want? Laughter!
BY THE HEAVENS ABOVE, YOU WILL SWEAR THERE'S NOTHING RARER!
Guido.
You're saving the movie. Give him a good idea, for God's sake.
That I would pay to see.
She was the best thing in the movie.
Claudia says where are you? She's in fine form. Feisty.
She asked if she could read my script as she didn't have one. I said I didn't quite have mine.
Thank you.
I'm glad she's acting again. I made her costumes for the play. She's funny.
Guido, she's my friend. I'm not her mother. I don't know. I expect so.
And where are you getting about?
Are you seeing anybody?
Well, it sounds exciting. Walking around and not seeing anyone, growing a beard.   I might come up here and join you.
- I know.
Luisa certainly thinks so.
Stop! I'm not going to act as a postman between you both. Come back to Rome. Make a movie. Go to work.
You're such a dope, aren't you?

Guido - there probably isn't a single person passing by who hasn't been touched in some way by one of your movies. That's your gift. That's what you've been given. Use it. Just use it with some grace. For Chrissake.
Sounds perfect.
The costumes might not be so bad too.
Oh, Guido, Guido.
This is your Rome, Guido. The world sees Rome the way you invented it.
I miss you, too.
I am ashamed of you, Guido.
Guido? Dove corri? Where are you running to?
...Caro,caro mio.
No one can help you find your way.
It's up to you, Guido. Up to you.
And we're just waiting for the arrival of Contini...any moment now - Could this film put the Maestro back on top?
And here he is..!
Dante, Guido Contini's long time producer, is about to speak...
Maestro Contini. Maestro Contini.
Grazie. Maestro Contini, your new film is called Italia... big title.
But hardly a modest one.
And might you tell the press what the film is about?
That was the problem. Nobody else did.
Is this true?
Signor Contini. Artists do their best work before they're famous. Now you're famous. Without wishing to be negative - but your last two films, they're not, they were...
Your word. Flops.
I'm just asking if you're nervous?
What I'm asking, Maestro, is have you run out of things to say?
Signor Contini.
Grazie. Could you tell the fashionable women of America who your favorite designer is this year?
I was wondering if you think there's a limit to what you can show in a movie.
I'll have one of those. Due.
Hi, Guido Contini. Stephanie, from Vogue, remember me?
So, coincidence. You being here.    And me being here.
That was quite a performance. At the Press Conference. The Vanishing Act.
No, please, my treat.
Grazie.
I've seen all your movies.
Like a million times. They're the only movies that tell the truth about the modern world.
Death of religion... Sexual revolution...
That we can talk about later.
You have such style. I always think that. That's the other thing I love about your movies.
Every frame is like a postcard.
It's great: you care as much about the suit as the man wearing it.
It's the Italian man in you: pays for your drinks, undresses you with his eyes...

No! Style is the new content! It's what my readers love. They want to dress like Claudia Jenssen. They want to undress like Claudia Jenssen. They want to ride on a Vespa down the Via Veneto. They want to live in an Italian movie.
I LOVE THE BLACK AND WHITE!
WHATEVER GUIDO DOES, IT MAKES ME SMILE HE IS THE ESSENCE OF ITALIAN STYLE.
Signor Contini! You're a man of the world, yes? Educated in Britain, a home in Biarritz. With Italia is it fair to say that you've come home for good?
What do you think of the New Wave in the French Cinema?
It's been a long time since you made a movie with your wife, do you plan on casting her in this new film?
But she hasn't worked at all since working with you.
But why are you being so tight-lipped about this film? It's a serious question. What's the big deal?
BUT NOT HAVE TO BELIEVE IN GOD.
THAT SOME IDIOT WENT AND TOLD.
ARRANGE IT!
CONTINI, CONTINI, CONTINI, CONTINI...
CONTINI, CONTINI, CONTINI, CONTINI...
GUIDO!
Of course.
Yes.
All of our suites have air... let me just look for you.
I understand.
Would Maestro Contini prefer to register under a pseudonym?
Signor Milano?
Needless to say, I love your films.
Consider it done. Please.
You can take the call at the lobby phone over there.
Your doctor is on his way.
It's a wrong number.
Signor Contini, it's the Signora.
Signora, would you rather wait inside?
There you are.
Well, I'm mad at you.   Where are you?
I heard. Dramatic.
You're making a film. You make a film, you get sick. It's what happens.
Are you by yourself?
Then shall I come?
Okay.
I don't know where you are.
Well I can't come if I don't know where you are.
Yes, it's hardly worth it.
Get some rest, take the waters, sleep, then come back here and make a good movie.
Get better.
The jungle drums said it was an emergency.
Not entirely.
You haven't been sleeping.
Am I already going home?
I do now.
Thank you for calling.
It was Monday.
Thank you.
Sit down, won't you, Don Mario?
Please.
I was.
Can't you?
GUIDO CONTINI, LUISA CONTINI: NUMBER ONE GENIUS AND NUMBER ONE FAN.
My father's Italian. My mother's French.
Oh, I've waited...
Waited tables.
And, of course, I studied theatre and mime in Paris. But, mostly waited tables.
For what?
LONG AGO - SOMEONE ELSE AGO.
Excuse me, I suddenly feel very tired.
I'm staggered by my own stupidity.    I could vomit.
You open your mouth and a lie comes out.
Why am I surprised? - it's like breathing to you.
Very plausible.
You told me it was finished.
Nothing. If you could see yourself.
I couldn't live with it - the absurdity of being you, the effort of having to hide and lie and cheat. It's exhausting, no wonder you've got no script, you're too busy inventing your own life.
Blah blah blah blah blah.
Pronto.
Go on.
YOU WANT MY LOVE?
Thank you.
Thank you for reminding me I'm not special. You don't even see what you do, do you? Even the moments I think are ours, it's just you working to get what you want.
YOU WANT MY GLOVE?
And this is our life. You think to create is to forgive yourself in public. Fine. But don't think I can forgive you in private, because I can't ever.
I WATCH YOU RISE!
You're just an appetite, and if you stopped being greedy you'd die. You take everything, and I'm empty.
You know, I'm glad I came. I can see now... it's hopeless...
Dottore.
Doctor... His pulse... it's racing.
Si?
Signor Contini.
She took five or six pills, enough to make herself very sick. I understand she's your mistress.
This is a sordid business. You movie people, I suppose you don't consider yourself bound by morality...
Check again.
Stress.    Exhaustion.
Your liver, your heart, your kidneys, they're all very cross with you, Signore.
Open wide.
But you've come to the right place.
...the Roman emperors came here for the waters...
As you wish.
Is something wrong?
GUIDO...
GUIDO...
WHO'S NOT WEARING ANY CLOTHES?
COOTCHIE, COOTCHIE, COOTCHIE COO.
